reviewText: This movie was so much needed for people to try to learn about depression/bipolar/aspergers etc. It needs to be taught as people think a person is crazy etc and it is such a shame. No one wants to talk about mental illness it seems. Thank you for the good job on this movie.

reviewText: I was looking to gain a deeper insight into some of the above conditions so as to better understand my clients and friends who are trying to cope with and function with their handicaps. A broader perspective of each individual disability discussing the latest information, the optimum approach and best method to assist persons with such difficulties would have been more practical and useful. Would I watch this movie again or recommend others to watch it? Probably not.

reviewText: I thought this would be more interesting but the film maker was just making a film about himself and it never came to any kind of point.  Lots of people are depressed or have Asperger's or OCD but I guess I needed to know what he is doing to cope with it or some other conclusion.  Maybe it did come to a conclusion but I couldn't watch it to the end.  It was too boring.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Mental illness needs understanding, compassion and medical treatment. To be able to recognize the components is not a simple thing. For those who need treatment, understanding doesn't always come easily or with the support of family and friends. Psychiatry and psychology needs to find that 'bridge' to the psyche and in some cases provide or encourage the basic building blocks.This video opens the doorway to  understanding multiple diagnoses and treatments.Obsessive Compulsive DisorderMajor DepressionBipolarAsperger'sA formidable combination of diagnoses that can only reek havoc within life. Take the time to listen and learn. Without knowledge, how can one begin to comprehend the reality?  A remarkably honest look into the life of one who lives with mental illness and offers a glimpse of hope. Recommended for those with mental illness and for those that are 'caregivers.' Highly recommended for anyone who wants to understand a part of the reality of living with mental illness.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Very Personal look into this mans life and a few big surprises about he and his family that really keep it interesting.  A good view for most anyone and gets a "don't hesitate" from me.

reviewText: If you have experience with mental health or not this is a good film to get a bit of an inside look. Granted, not all people affected have the same symptoms or issues but Clayman is honest and open about what is going on in his head.

reviewText: This documentary all about the life of Bradford (Buddy) Clayman is truly a wonder to behold.  What is initially striking is just how personable Buddy is, with all he now must undertake just to get through one single day.  I felt honored to have been included into a snippet of his situation.People having something to say with this kind of rare honesty is not a situation that I ever really expect, it takes a bravery and candor that will and does lift it up.  His attitude toward his new-found life at age 47 is the glue that holds Buddy together in society with this type of severe mental illness.  I was amazed at each and every turn he made, with his therapist who suffers from the affliction of OCD himself, his friends, and with his parents' loving support.Buddy explains to one of his Dr.s (Sally Gever PhD) about what "OC87" means to him.  It is actually a state of mind when his Obsessive-Compulsive thoughts are overtaking him; "out of control of everything" is a dark and terrifying place for him.  He must constantly be aware of and talk himself through thought-processes that would come into our minds so quickly that we don't even notice them.  With Buddy, "these words are a command" (his therapist, Jonathan Grayson PhD, teaches him) and Buddy must choose an action in these terribly difficult times.  The film teaches all the different types and ways these thoughts are so intrusive.The group therapy sessions lend such valuable insight to experiences that people who suffer from mental illness go through everyday.  The kinds of things that can seem as easy as making a decision are difficult for some and impossible for others.  Feelings are forgotten as soon as a person leaves.  Remembering those feelings felt within the experience is impossible.  This is just a minor look into Asperger's Syndrome (Neuro-biologically based, Autistic-Spectrum Disorder), for Buddy, OCD and the former overlap at times.  Actor and friend Maurice Benard ("Sonny Corinthos" of 'General Hospital'), weighs in about the Bipolar aspect of Buddy's illness.  They shared a "breakdown" on the exact date and "feel a connection because of their shared struggle".I am amazed with writer-filmmaker Buddy Clayman.  His documentary is brilliant and insightful also inspiring for this look into what it is to suffer such illnesses ... The Documentary is definitely personal; therefore, Thank you and Bravo Buddy!
summary: "...I Don't Feel I'm In Control At All - On This Project!" - Buddy Clayman
Title: N/A

reviewText: I believe in my heart that everyone has some sort of disability some are seen and others are not.  Of course, some have it  rougher than others.  I personally related so much with Buddy becasue I too have suffered from social anxiety and depression most of my life.  Fortunately, I hid it well and was able to get married and have a family, but it is and always will be a life long struggle.  What inspired me the most was how rough Bud had it and now seems well on his way to deal with his illness and start the life he so much deserves.  His likeable personality made you root for him thoroughut the movie and he gave me and others with a form of mental illness hope.Thank you Buddy and I wish you the best.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I liked Bud Clayman's documentary and he shows what it's like to live with obsessive compulsive disorder on a daily basis.
